title: 106_hr910
content: The Act titled "San Gabriel Basin Water Quality Initiative" focuses on the restoration of the San Gabriel Basin. The San Gabriel Basin Restoration Fund is established within the Treasury of the United States for restoration purposes. It will be administered by the Secretary of the Army in cooperation with the San Gabriel Basin Water Quality Authority. The San Gabriel Basin Restoration Fund will be utilized by the Secretary to design, construct, operate, and maintain water quality projects administered by the San Gabriel Basin Water Quality Authority and the Central Basin Municipal Water District. The Secretary is limited to obligating funds after depositing them in the Fund, with a cost-sharing limitation in place. The San Gabriel Basin Water Quality Authority is responsible for providing a non-Federal amount to ensure 35 percent of funds obligated by the Secretary come from non-Federal interests. Compliance with applicable laws is required, and this section does not affect other authorities used for cleanup and protection of the San Gabriel and Central groundwater basins. Authorization of Appropriations: $85,000,000 is authorized to be appropriated to the Restoration Fund, with $10,000,000 set aside for the Central Basin Water Quality Project. These funds shall remain available until expended. SEC. 3. PERCHLORATE. The Secretary is authorized to participate in studies and projects to address groundwater contamination from perchlorates, including investigations in Texas watersheds impacted by a former Naval plant. The Secretary is authorized to participate in investigations and projects related to perchlorate contamination in Caddo Lake, Texas and Santa Clarita, California. $25,000,000 is authorized for these activities, with specific allocations for each subsection. Funds exceeding $3,000,000 for subsection (b)(2) and up to $7,000,000 for subsection (b)(3) are allocated for specific activities related to perchlorate contamination in Caddo Lake, Texas and Santa Clarita, California. The House of Representatives passed the bill on March 28, 2000.
